quiz.title: Physics 11: Unit 5 Quiz 4
quiz.subtitle: Statics: Torque and the Principle of Moments
quiz.subject: Physics 11
quiz.topic: Torque, Lever Arms, and Rotational Equilibrium

questions.question: A 5.00 kg mass is placed 2.00 m to the left of a pivot. Where should a 10.0 kg mass be placed to the right to balance the system?
questions.explanation: For equilibrium, CCW torque = CW torque. (m1 × g × d1) = (m2 × g × d2). The 'g' cancels out: 5.00 kg × 2.00 m = 10.0 kg × d2. 10.0 = 10.0 × d2. d2 = 1.00 m.

questions.question: What is the torque produced by a 20.0 N force applied perpendicularly to a wrench at a distance of 0.25 m from the bolt?
questions.explanation: Torque (τ) = Force (F) × lever arm (r). τ = 20.0 N × 0.25 m = 5.00 N·m.

questions.question: A uniform log of length 4.00 m is balanced at its center. A 15.0 kg child sits on the left end (2.00 m from pivot). A second child sits 1.50 m to the right of the pivot to balance it. What is the mass of the second child?
A 2.00 m long lever has a pivot at the far left end. A 50.0 N force pushes upward at the far right end. What is the torque about the pivot?
questions.explanation: τ = F × r. τ = 50.0 N × 2.00 m = 100 N·m. Since the force is upward on the right side of the pivot, it rotates the lever counter-clockwise.

questions.question: Two masses are balanced on a lever. If the mass on the right is doubled, what must happen to its distance from the pivot to maintain balance?
questions.explanation: Since τ = F × d, if Force (mass) is multiplied by 2, the distance must be divided by 2 to keep the product constant.

questions.question: A 10.0 kg uniform plank is 4.00 m long. If the pivot is placed exactly at the 1.00 m mark from the left end, what downward force must be applied at the left end to keep the plank horizontal?
questions.explanation: The plank's weight (10kg × 9.8) acts at its center (2m mark). The distance from pivot (1m mark) to center is 1m. CW Torque from plank = 98N × 1m = 98 N·m. To balance, Force_left × 1m = 98 N·m. Force = 98.0 N.

questions.question: A person uses a 1.50 m long crowbar. They apply a force of 200 N at the end. If the pivot is 0.10 m from the load, what is the torque applied to the crowbar by the person?
questions.explanation: The person is at the far end, so their distance from the pivot is 1.50 m - 0.10 m = 1.40 m. Torque = 200 N × 1.40 m = 280 N·m.

questions.question: Which of the following describes 'Rotational Equilibrium'?
options: The sum of all torques is zero
The object is not moving at all
The sum of all forces is zero
The object is moving at a constant tangential speed
The pivot is located at the center of mass
questions.explanation: Translational equilibrium means net Force is zero. Rotational equilibrium specifically means the net Torque is zero.

questions.question: A 60.0 kg person stands 2.00 m from the pivot of a seesaw. A 40.0 kg person stands on the other side. How far must the 40.0 kg person stand from the pivot to balance?
If a force is applied directly through the pivot point (r = 0), what is the resulting torque?
questions.explanation: Torque is the product of force and lever arm distance. If the distance (r) is zero, the torque is zero, regardless of the force magnitude.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a firm grasp of the Principle of Moments.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Be careful when the pivot is not in the center; remember to account for the weight of the lever itself at its center of mass.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Torque = Force × Distance. Make sure distance is measured from the pivot!
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the balance: (Mass 1 × Distance 1) = (Mass 2 × Distance 2).
